questions.text: A 5-year-old presents with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory papillomatosis

 

The given clinical situation suggests that the child is suffering from respiratory papillomatosis.

 

Respiratory Papillomatosis (Juvenile Papillomatosis)

 

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11.
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Age 3-5 years
  • Hoarseness or aphonia
  • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy

 

 

Treatment consists of cold steel/ coblation/ debrider/ radiofrequency/ Laser assisted microlaryngeal surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Croup: Though croup affects young children and presents with respiratory symptoms, it is an acute condition that generally presents rapidly with a characteristic barking cough and stridor, not gradually as in this case.

 

Option C. Vocal nodule: Vocal nodules result from vocal cord trauma and present symmetrically on the free edge of the vocal cords at the junction of the anterior one-third and the posterior two-thirds. They typically cause hoarseness but do not lead to respiratory distress, as they do not obstruct the airway.

 

Option D. Acute epiglottitis: This is another acute condition, presenting with rapid onset and severe symptoms including high fever, throat pain, and significant respiratory distress. The progressive nature of the symptoms described in the question does not align with the acute presentation of epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:


Juvenile respiratory papillomatosis should be considered in young children presenting with a gradual worsening of hoarseness and the development of respiratory symptoms. The condition highlights the need for awareness of HPV-related diseases in children and indicates the importance of early and accurate diagnosis followed by appropriate surgical intervention, which may include cold steel, coblation, debrider, radiofrequency, or laser-assisted microlaryngeal surgery to manage the growth and recurrence of papillomas effectively.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 327, 328, 343, 345, 346

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper airway examination

 

The image shows a tracheostomy tube, which is not used for upper airway examination.

 

Tracheostomy:

 

  • It is a procedure where alternative airway is established when normal airway is compromised.
  • An opening is made on the anterior wall of trachea and a tube is inserted, through which air exchange occurs between lungs and outside.
  • It bypasses upper airway structures from nose to larynx thereby reducing the dead space by 50%.
  • Usually done at the level of 2nd to 3rd tracheal rings.
  • High tracheostomy (1st ring) done along with surgeries related to cancer larynx.
  • In emergency tracheostomy, vertical incision is taken but in elective cases, horizontal incision is taken.
  • It is generally a temporary procedure till the pathology in the upper bypassed airway clears.
  • In some cases, like cancer larynx where laryngectomy was done, permanent tracheostomy is done.
  • Removal of tracheostomy tube is called decannulation.
  • Different types of tracheostomy tubes – PVC, Metallic (Chevalier-Jackson), etc.
  • Complications of tracheostomy → surgical emphysema, hemorrhage, Apnea due to CO2 washout, Pneumothorax, Tube displacement, Tube blockage, Tracheomalacia, Subglottic stenosis

 

Other Options:

 

Primary Uses of a Tracheostomy Tube Include:

 

Option A. Airway Toileting: Facilitates the removal of secretions from the airways.

 

Option C. Acute Nasopharyngeal Obstruction: Provides an airway bypass in cases of blockage in the upper airway.

 

Option D. Prolonged Mechanical Ventilation: Offers a secure, stable method for long-term ventilation support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracheostomy tubes are not used for examining the upper airway as they do not provide access or visibility to upper airway structures such as the nasal passages, pharynx, or larynx. Instead, tools like laryngoscopes or endoscopes are employed for this purpose.

questions.text: Which structures pass between superior and middle constrictor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal Nerve)

 

The pharyngeal constrictor muscles are organized into three main parts: the superior, middle, and inferior constrictors. Each of these muscles plays a crucial role in the mechanics of swallowing and speech.

 

The glossopharyngeal nerve passes between the superior and middle constrictor muscles. This is a key anatomical relationship to remember as it is crucial for the nerve supply to the pharynx.

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian Tube: Passes through the sinus of Morgagni, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option C. Superior Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the middle and inferior constrictors, not the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Option D. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: Passes between the inferior constrictor and the esophagus, not between the superior and middle constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IX nerve (Glossopharyngeal nerve) and the stylopharyngeus muscle pass between the superior and middle constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

questions.text: The provided picture shows a patient who has undergone mastoidectomy. Identify the lateral semicircular canal in the image. (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

In the given image of a post-mastoidectomy surgical field, label A corresponds to the lateral semicircular canal. The lateral semicircular canal is a crucial component of the inner ear's vestibular system, involved in maintaining balance and spatial orientation. It can be identified by its specific location relative to other anatomical landmarks visible in the image, such as the tympanic bone, mastoid tip, and the spine of Henle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: This label points to the posterior semicircular canal, which is a bony protrusion in the mastoid portion of the temporal bone, serving as an important landmark during mastoid surgery.

 

Option C: This indicates the sigmoid sinus, a dural venous sinus within the skull, lying beneath the cranial bone and above the structures of the middle and inner ear.

 

Option D: Labelled as the Tegmen, which is part of the temporal bone that forms the roof over the middle ear and mastoid antrum, shielding these structures from the intracranial contents.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The lateral semicircular canal, identified at label A, is part of the vestibular system, crucial for balance and orientation.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaint of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial nerve

 

The given clinical features of inability to close the eye, drooling of saliva, and deviation of the angle of the mouth are suggestive of paralysis of the facial nerve.

 

Bell's palsy is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset.

 

Etiology –

 

  1. Viral infection  - herpes simplex, herpes zoster, EBV
  2. Vascular ischemia
  3. Heredity – narrow fallopian canal
  4. Autoimmune

 

Clinical features -

 

Onset is sudden. Patient is unable to close his eyes. On attempting to close the eye, the eyeball turns up and out (Bell phenomenon). Saliva dribbles from the angle of mouth. Face becomes asymmetrical. Tears flow down from the eye (epiphora). Pain in the ear may precede or accompany nerve paralysis. Some complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). Paralysis may be complete or incomplete. Bell palsy is recurrent in 3–10% of patients.

 

 

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations.

 

Treatment of Bell's palsy -

 

  • Prednisolone is the drug of choice. If a patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone is 1 mg/kg/day divided into morning and evening doses for 5 days. Patient is seen on the fifth day. If paralysis is incomplete or is recovering, the dose is tapered during the next 5 days. If paralysis remains complete, the same dose is continued for another 10 days and thereafter tapered in next 5 days (total of 20 days).
  • Eye care to prevent keratitis
  • Analgesic for ear pain
  • Physiotherapy

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Mainly responsible for facial sensation, not motor control.

 

Option C. Oculomotor nerve: Primarily influences eye movement; paralysis typically results in ptosis and pupillary dilation, not facial drooping.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal nerve: Affects swallowing and taste sensations at the back of the tongue; does not cause facial drooping or affect eye closure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prompt recognition and treatment of facial nerve paralysis are crucial for improving outcomes and preventing permanent damage. Treatment primarily involves medication to reduce inflammation and supportive care, especially for eye protection.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 103, 104

choices.text: Vocal cord nodules
Vocal cord polyp

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the ENT clinic by his parents due to persistent hoarseness and difficulty breathing, which have progressively worsened over the past several months. The parents report that his voice has become increasingly raspy, and he often struggles with noisy breathing, especially during physical activity. There is no history of recent respiratory infections or trauma. On flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy, lesions observed on his vocal cords (as shown in below image). The physician suspects a viral etiology associated with these lesions. What is the diagnosis of the vocal cord lesion shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Laryngeal papilloma

 

Explanation:


Laryngeal papillomatosis, commonly referred to as laryngeal papilloma, is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children. It is caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11 and is often acquired at birth from mothers with genital HPV infection. The lesions typically present as wart-like growths on the vocal cords, affecting the glottic and supraglottic regions but can extend to other parts of the respiratory tract. Patients usually present with hoarseness, stridor, or respiratory difficulty, and the diagnosis is confirmed through laryngoscopy and biopsy. Recurrence is common, and treatment involves microlaryngoscopy with CO2 laser excision, with the primary goal of maintaining airway patency and preserving vocal function.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Vocal cord nodules: These are benign growths on the vocal cords caused by vocal strain or overuse, presenting as bilateral, symmetrical lesions. They typically do not have the viral etiology or recurrence pattern seen in laryngeal papillomas.

 

Option C. Vocal cord polyp: Polyps are unilateral, fluid-filled lesions that develop due to vocal trauma, smoking, or other irritants. Unlike papillomas, they are not caused by HPV and are generally managed with conservative voice therapy or surgical removal.

 

Option D. Reinke’s edema: This condition involves the swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation, commonly associated with smoking or vocal overuse. It presents with a deep, gravelly voice but lacks the warty appearance of papillomas.

 

Educational Objective:


Laryngeal papillomatosis is caused by HPV types 6 and 11 and is characterized by recurrent wart-like lesions on the vocal cords, leading to hoarseness and respiratory difficulties. Early recognition and treatment through microlaryngoscopy with CO2 laser excision are essential to manage symptoms, maintain airway patency, and preserve vocal quality.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway:(INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-1-3-4-5

 

The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is spiral ganglion - cochlear nucleus - superior olivary nucleus - inferior colliculus - medial geniculate body.

 

2. Spiral Ganglion : The spiral ganglion is situated in Rosenthal's canal and contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve, which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

 

1. Cochlear Nucleus : The cochlear nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

3. Superior Olivary Nucleus : After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary nucleus.

 

4. Inferior Colliculus : From the superior olivary nucleus, the auditory signals travel to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

5. Medial Geniculate Body : The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

 

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  2. Cochlear Nucleus
  3. Superior Olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex

questions.text: A person presents with a tongue ulcer persisting for 3 months. Upon examination, a lesion measuring 3.5 cm x 2.5 cm is observed, accompanied by an 8 mm area of hardened tissue. No lymph node enlargement is detected. According to the 8th AJCC guidelines, what stage does this lesion correspond to? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage II

 

In the given case can be classified as T2N0M0 as per AJCC 2002 as the size of the lesion is between 2-4 cm (T2) with no nodal (N0) or distant metastasis (M0) and that will come under Stage II disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage I: This stage would be applicable for T1 tumors, which are 2 cm or less in greatest dimension, and does not fit the description of the lesion presented.

 

Option C. Stage III: This stage would involve either T3 tumors, which are greater than 4 cm, or any T1-T3 tumors with N1 lymph node involvement, neither of which applies to this case.

 

Option D. Stage IV: This stage is reserved for more advanced disease involving T4 tumors, any tumor with N2 or N3 lymph node involvement, or distant metastasis (M1), which are not applicable in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 256

questions.text:
Mark the correct statement/s about Inner and Outer hair cells. (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses
  2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate function of inner hair cells
  3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for movement of tectorial membrane
  4. Inner hair cells are in single row and modulate function of outer hair cells
  5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 5 are correct 

This choice correctly identifies that inner hair cells transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in multiple rows and aid in the functionality related to cochlear amplification, and that there is a numerical dominance of outer hair cells compared to inner hair cells. 

The correct statements regarding the roles and arrangements of inner and outer hair cells within the cochlea, based on the options given, are as follows:

1. Inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses: This statement is correct. Inner hair cells are primarily responsible for transmitting auditory signals to the brain. They are fewer in number compared to outer hair cells and are arranged in a single row along the length of the cochlea.

2. Outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and modulate the function of inner hair cells: This is correct. Outer hair cells are indeed arranged in 3-4 rows. They play a crucial role in amplifying and fine-tuning the vibrations within the cochlea through their motility, which affects how the inner hair cells respond to sound. 

5. Outer and inner hair cells are present in the ratio 3:1: This statement is  correct. There are significantly more outer hair cells than inner hair cells, typically at a ratio close to 3:1, reflecting their arrangement in multiple rows compared to the single row of inner hair cells.

Other Options:

3. Outer hair cells are more responsible for the movement of the tectorial membrane: This statement is incorrect. Outer hair cells do contribute to the movement of the tectorial membrane through their motility and changes in length, but it's more accurate to say they influence the fluid mechanics around the inner hair cells, affecting how the tectorial membrane interacts with them.

4. Inner hair cells are in a single row and modulate function of outer hair cells: This statement is incorrect. Inner hair cells do not modulate the function of outer hair cells; rather, they function primarily as sensory transducers sending information to the brain.

Educational Objective: 

The correct statements about inner and outer hair cells are that inner hair cells are in a single row and transmit auditory impulses, outer hair cells are in 3-4 rows and help modulate cochlear mechanics, and the ratio of outer to inner hair cells is about 3:1.

questions.text: A senior ENT specialist at the hospital is conducting the clinical examination depicted in the provided image. Which of the subsequent anatomical structures will not be visible to him? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arytenoids

 

While conducting a posterior rhinoscopy with the held post-nasal mirror, the specialist would not have a view of the arytenoids.

 

  • Arytenoids are seen on indirect laryngoscopy.
  • The posterior rhinoscopy mirror has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.
  • The structures seen in posterior rhinoscopy are:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoids: These are clearly visible during posterior rhinoscopy, which is aimed at examining the nasopharynx, where the adenoids are located.

 

Option C. Torus tubarius: This structure, which surrounds the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube, is also visible during a posterior rhinoscopy.

 

Option D. Upper surface of soft palate: This area can be inspected during posterior rhinoscopy for signs of inflammation, lesions, or other abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The arytenoids are viewed using indirect laryngoscopy, not posterior rhinoscopy, due to their location in the larynx. Posterior rhinoscopy provides visualization of the nasopharyngeal region, aiding in the assessment of structures like adenoids, torus tubarius, and the upper surface of the soft palate, important for diagnosing various nasopharyngeal conditions.

 

Additional Information

 

Structures seen on indirect laryngoscopy

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior metal wall
Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about keratosis obturans? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

All of the above statements are true regarding keratosis obturans.

 

  • Collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus is called keratosis obturans. This, by its pressure effect, causes absorption of bone leading to widening of the meatus so much so that facial nerves may be exposed and paralyzed.
  • Presenting symptoms may be pain in the ear, hearing loss, tinnitus and sometimes ear discharge. It may sometimes be associated with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
  • On examination, the ear canal may be full of pearly white mass of keratin material disposed in several layers. Removal of this mass may show widening of bony meatus with ulceration and even granuloma formation.

 

 

Treatment

 

Keratotic mass is removed either by syringing or instrumentation, similar to the techniques employed for impacted wax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Keratosis obturans is characterized by the accumulation of epithelial cells in the ear canal, leading to potential structural damage and associated symptoms. Its management requires careful removal of the buildup and monitoring for complications such as facial nerve palsy. Awareness of its association with bronchiectasis and sinusitis is crucial for comprehensive patient care.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip. There is a past history of FESS (Functional endoscopic sinus surgery) for failed conservative management 5 years ago. Uncinectomy and maxillary ostium dilation was done during the previous FESS. A DNE done now shows patent ostia and mucosal edema of the maxillary sinus lining. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroid irrigation and antihistamines

 

The next best step in management in this patient is steroid irrigation and antihistamines.

 

This patient who had previously undergone FESS 5 years ago for failed medical management now has nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip suggestive of acute rhinosinusitis.

 

Acute rhinosinusitis usually develops along with viral upper respiratory tract infection due to mucosal swelling causing obstruction of the sinus ostia. Persistent or worsening symptoms even after 10 days with fever and purulent discharge indicates secondary bacterial infection.

 

Treatment initially is symptomatic with -

 

  • First line of treatment - Nasal steroid irrigation, decongestants, and antihistamines
  • In cases of secondary bacterial infection antibiotics are indicated. Amoxyclav is the drug of choice.
  • Biological therapy is not used in the treatment of sinusitis. It may be used in cases of refractory polyp.
  • Revision surgery is indicated only when maximal medical therapy has failed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat Surgery: Indicated only if there are anatomical obstructions or complications that cannot be managed medically. In this case, the DNE shows patent ostia, so repeat surgery is not indicated without further evidence of structural issues.

 

Option B. Macrolides for 4 months: Could be considered for their anti-inflammatory properties in some chronic rhinosinusitis cases, but there is no mention of bacterial infection needing long-term antibiotics, making this less suitable than symptomatic management.

 

Option D. Biological Therapy: Mainly used for refractory cases with specific underlying conditions such as severe asthma or nasal polyps, which is not indicated here based on the provided scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with nasal obstruction and post-nasal drip post-FESS with no current acute infection or structural issues, conservative management using steroid irrigation and antihistamines is recommended to manage inflammation and alleviate symptoms.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 213, 214

choices.text: Multiple tympanic membrane perforations
Painless ear discharge

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a known history of pulmonary tuberculosis presents to the ENT clinic with a persistent symptoms inhis right ear that has been ongoing for several months. He has noticed progressive hearing loss. Otoscopic examination reveals signs of chronic mastoid involvement.. The physician suspects tuberculous otitis media given the patient's history and clinical findings. Which of the following is not a characteristic of tuberculous otitis media?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Earache

 

Explanation:


Tuberculous otitis media is a chronic form of middle ear infection caused by the spread of tuberculosis from another site, commonly the lungs. The disease progresses slowly and insidiously, leading to painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane, which often results in multiple perforations that can coalesce into a larger defect. Patients typically present with painless, foul-smelling ear discharge, hearing loss, and possible complications like facial paralysis, mastoiditis, and postauricular fistulas. Unlike other forms of otitis media, earache is notably absent in tuberculous otitis media, making the lack of pain a distinguishing feature of this condition.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Multiple tympanic membrane perforations: This is a common feature of tuberculous otitis media, where the disease causes multiple small perforations that may merge into a larger one due to the painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane.

 

Option C. Painless ear discharge: The ear discharge in tuberculous otitis media is characteristically foul-smelling and painless, differentiating it from other ear infections that often cause pain.

 

Option D. Facial paralysis: Facial nerve paralysis can occur due to the spread of infection to the facial nerve, commonly seen in advanced cases of tuberculous otitis media.

 

Educational Objective:


Tuberculous otitis media is a painless middle ear infection associated with multiple tympanic membrane perforations, foul-smelling discharge, and potential complications such as facial paralysis and mastoiditis. Recognizing the absence of earache is crucial for distinguishing this condition from other types of otitis media, aiding in timely and appropriate management.

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.text: A patient present with oral cavity findings as seen in the image below. He is a smoker. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

 

  • The next step of management of this patient will be cessation of smoking and do a biopsy.
  • The patient is a chronic smoker and the following image shows leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity.

 

The management include: 

 

  1. Elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion. Many of the lesions will disappear spontaneously if the causative agent is removed.
  2. In lesions with higher potential for malignant change, a biopsy is taken to rule out malignancy.
  3. In suspicious small lesions, surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

 

A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long term follow up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give corticosteroids: There is no role for corticosteroids in the treatment of leukoplakia as they do not address the potential for malignant transformation or the underlying causes of the lesion.

 

Option C. Lifestyle Modifications: While beneficial overall, lifestyle changes alone are insufficient for managing a lesion with potential malignancy. Specific interventions like quitting smoking are required.

 

Option D. Injection vitamin B12: There is no indication that vitamin B12 injections would be effective in treating leukoplakia unless there is a specific deficiency that also needs addressing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For leukoplakia, particularly in smokers, the primary management strategy includes cessation of smoking and histological examination through biopsy. This is crucial not only to assess the current state of the lesion but also to guide further therapeutic decisions which may include surgical excision, laser ablation, or cryotherapy depending on the biopsy results. Regular monitoring and photographic documentation of the lesion are also important for long-term follow-up.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 253

questions.text:
What is the grade of tympanic membrane retraction shown in the image?

(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
✅ Correct Answer: B. Grade 2

📸 Image Analysis:

The otoscopic image shows a retracted pars tensa where deeper middle ear structures like the long process of the incus and incudostapedial joint are visible. The lateral process of the malleus is prominently seen, and the tympanic membrane appears pulled medially, but it is not adherent to the promontory, and air is still visible in the middle ear. This presentation is typical of Grade 2 retraction.

🔍 Explanation of Options:

Option A: Grade 1

In Grade 1 pars tensa retraction, there is only mild inward retraction. The cone of light is lost, the fibrous annulus appears more prominent, and the handle of the malleus becomes more medialized. Importantly, there is no contact with the ossicles, and ossicular landmarks like the incus are not visible. This does not match the findings seen in the image.

 

Option B: Grade 2

Grade 2 retraction is more severe than Grade 1, and the pars tensa is retracted to the extent that it touches the long process of the incus. Deeper structures like the incudostapedial joint, round window niche, and even the horizontal facial canal may be visible. The tympanic membrane still retains some mobility and is not adherent to the promontory. This fits the otoscopic image exactly, where ossicular structures are seen but no signs of complete adhesion are present.

 

Option C: Grade 3

In Grade 3 retraction, the tympanic membrane is severely retracted and becomes adherent to the promontory, forming what is called an atelectatic membrane. Although some air may still remain in the middle ear, the drum is essentially collapsed onto the medial wall. This condition is more advanced than what is seen in the current image.

 

Option D: Grade 4

This is the most severe stage where the entire tympanic membrane is stuck to the promontory, and there is complete loss of middle ear aeration. It often leads to adhesive otitis media, and ossicular erosion (such as necrosis of the incus) may occur. This is clearly not the case here, as ossicles are intact and the membrane is not fully adherent.

🧠 Educational Objective:

Grade 2 pars tensa retraction is identified when the tympanic membrane retracts to touch the long process of the incus without adhering to the promontory, often revealing middle ear ossicles such as the incudostapedial joint.

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of reactionary hemorrhage post-tonsillectomy and the immediate management is to shift the patient to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the bleeding vessel.

 

Hemorrhage is a common complication of tonsillectomy. It can be primary, reactionary, or secondary:

 

  • Primary hemorrhage occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or blood pressure returning to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels is done under anesthesia if the above measures fail.
  • Secondary hemorrhage is usually seen between the 5th to 10th postoperative day. It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Removal of the clot, topical application of dilute adrenaline or hydrogen peroxide with pressure usually suffice. IV antibiotics are given and the bleeding vessel is electro coagulated or ligated if bleeding continues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate return to the OT for direct intervention is essential in managing post-tonsillectomy bleeding. Ensuring the bleeding vessel is adequately addressed through cauterization or ligation can prevent further complications and promote healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 504, 505

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of minor trauma 20 days back with a piece of wood. He presented as shown in the image. CT scan revealed clear sinuses and the presence of subcutaneous nodules. Microscopy of the tissue sections are positive to PAS and positive on Gomori methamine silver stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phycomycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Phycomycosis /Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midline lethal granuloma: Primarily involves destructive lesions of the midline facial structures but lacks the fungal component.

 

Option B. Foreign body granuloma: Typically arises from a reaction to a foreign material but would not cause the extensive symptoms or be positive on the fungal stains used.

 

Option D. IgG4 granuloma: Associated with elevated levels of IgG4 and typically presents with tumefactive lesions, not primarily infectious.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phycomycosis is a serious fungal infection affecting mainly the nasal passages and sinuses, identifiable by special staining techniques and known for its aggressive, potentially fatal progression requiring prompt treatment with antifungals and surgery.

questions.text: Which of these structures are retained during radical neck dissection? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sublingual gland

 

In a radical neck dissection, the aim is to remove extensive lymphatic tissue potentially involved with malignancies, but the procedure generally spares certain non-lymphatic structures unless directly involved by the tumor. The sublingual gland, which is located under the floor of the mouth, is not typically removed during a radical neck dissection because it is not within the field of the lymph node groups that are typically excised. This gland remains intact unless the specific tumor pathology dictates otherwise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tail of parotid: The tail of the parotid may be removed if it is involved with the tumor or if the dissection needs to be extended to ensure comprehensive removal of cancerous tissues.

 

Option C. Submandibular gland: This gland is typically removed during radical neck dissections because it lies within the Level I lymph nodes, which are included in the dissection.

 

Option D. Level 2b lymph nodes: These are generally removed in a radical neck dissection, which traditionally includes the removal of lymph nodes from Levels I to V.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition Page No. 442; Stell and Maran 5th edition Page No. 710

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

questions.text: Which of these labeled structures represents a division of the internal carotid artery? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

The structure marked 1 and 4 are the anterior ethmoidal artery and posterior ethmoidal artery, which are branches of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vascular Supply of the Nasal Cavity:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 198

choices.text: Natural skin folds that align with relaxed muscle tension
Collagen fiber alignment lines used in wound healing prediction
Lines of facial expression that guide botulinum toxin injections
Anatomical landmarks indicating major blood vessels under the skin

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman consults a plastic surgeon regarding a planned facelift. She expresses concern about the potential for visible scarring after the surgery and inquires about techniques that minimize scarring. The surgeon discusses the process and importance of aligning incision along Kraissl’s line to optimize healing and achieve the best cosmetic results. What are Kraissl’s lines, and what is their significance in surgical practice?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Natural skin folds that align with relaxed muscle tension


Kraissl’s lines, also known as relaxed skin tension lines (RSTLs), are natural skin folds that align with relaxed muscle tension. These lines guide surgeons in placing incisions in cosmetic and reconstructive surgery to ensure the least visible scarring. Kraissl’s lines are determined by the natural resting state of the skin and are especially useful in areas such as the face, where minimizing scar visibility is crucial. They differ from other lines, like Langer’s lines, which are based on dermal collagen orientation.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Collagen fiber alignment lines used in wound healing prediction: This refers to Langer’s lines, which are based on the natural orientation of collagen fibers in the dermis. Langer’s lines guide incisions in a different context but are not the same as Kraissl’s lines.

 

Option C. Lines of facial expression that guide botulinum toxin injections: These are dynamic lines formed by repeated facial muscle movements, often targeted in aesthetic treatments like botulinum toxin injections but are not relevant to surgical incision planning.

 

Option D. Anatomical landmarks indicating major blood vessels under the skin: This describes vascular landmarks that guide surgeries to avoid major blood vessels, which are not related to Kraissl’s lines and have no impact on scar minimization.

 

Educational Objective:

 


Kraissl’s lines are natural skin folds that reflect areas of minimal tension and are used by surgeons to plan incisions for optimal cosmetic outcomes. Properly aligning incisions with these lines helps reduce visible scarring, making them crucial in cosmetic and reconstructive procedures.

questions.text: What is absent in a case of otitis media among the options provided? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Battle's sign

 

Battle's sign, characterized by ecchymosis (bruising) over the mastoid process, is typically indicative of a basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving the temporal bone. It is not associated with otitis media, which is an infection or inflammation of the middle ear.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bezold abscess: This abscess is a serious complication of otitis media. It occurs when the infection spreads from the mastoid process into the surrounding tissues, leading to a collection of pus.

Option B. Griesinger's sign: This sign is associated with lateral sinus thrombosis, a rare but severe complication of otitis media and mastoiditis. It involves tenderness and swelling behind the ear and along the mastoid bone.

Option D. Delta sign: Also related to lateral sinus thrombosis, the Delta sign typically appears on contrast-enhanced imaging studies as a NON enhancement at thrombosed area of sinus, a complication arising from otitis media.

Educational Objective:

 

While otitis media can lead to various complications, including Bezold abscess and lateral sinus thrombosis (indicated by Griesinger’s sign and Delta sign), Battle's sign is not associated with this condition. Instead, Battle's sign should prompt an evaluation for temporal bone fractures, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between signs of infection and trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 87, 93, 507

questions.text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meatoplasty

 

The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty.

 

It is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meats help easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning.

 

It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricle. Sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to retention of wax and difficulty in hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing.

 

Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only.

 

Option D: A cosmetic or reconstructive procedure aimed at correcting deformities or defects of the external part of the ear (pinna).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meatoplasty is an important surgical option for managing conditions that require improved access to the ear canal and middle ear, particularly in managing chronic ear diseases or anatomical changes that impact ear function.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 32, 457, 463

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otto veraguth folds

Allergic rhinitis is a condition characterized by symptoms such as sneezing, nasal congestion, runny nose, and itchy eyes. These symptoms can lead to several physical signs due to chronic inflammation and repetitive actions like rubbing the nose and eyes. However we do not see Otto Veraguth folds in Allergic Rhinitis.

 Also known as Veraguth folds, these are small creases on the upper eyelid and are not related to allergic rhinitis. They are typically associated with individuals suffering from depression, not allergic conditions.

Other Options:

Option A. Allergic Shiners: Commonly seen in allergic rhinitis due to venous congestion under the eyes.

Option B. Allergic Salute: A habitual action in allergic rhinitis leading to a nasal crease.

Option D. Dennis Morgan Lines: Found in chronic allergic conditions due to persistent inflammation and edema, including allergic rhinitis.

Educational Objective: 

Otto Veraguth folds are not associated with allergic rhinitis but are more commonly seen in individuals with depression.

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

The correct match for Wullstein’s classification is a-2, b-4, c-3, d-1

 

  1. Type II – 2. graft placed over the incus
  2. Type III – 4. columella tympanoplasty
  3. Type IV – 3. Cavum minor
  4. Type V – 1. Fenestration tympanoplasty

 

  1. Type II (Ossiculoplasty): Malleus partially eroded; ossicular chain reconstruction involves placing a graft over the incus.
  2. Type III (Columella Effect): Malleus and incus eroded; new TM coupled to the stapes head, referred to as columella tympanoplasty.
  3. Type IV (Cavum Minor): Stapedial head also eroded; new TM and new ossicular coupling to the stapes footplate.
  4. Type V (Fenestration Operation): Creating a fenestra and coupling the ossicular chain to the scala vestibuli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty provides a systematic approach to different types of middle ear reconstructions based on the extent of ossicular damage and required surgical repair.

questions.text: All of the following are major diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal culture

 

A positive fungal culture is a minor diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

This classification was detailed by Bent and Kuhn, who established criteria based on their findings of several clinical features important for the diagnosis of AFRS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of nasal polyps: Polyps are a common and significant finding in AFRS, often contributing to the blockage and symptoms of sinusitis.

 

Option B. Eosinophilic mucin: A hallmark of AFRS, this refers to thick, peanut butter-like mucin with eosinophils.

 

Option C. Characteristic CT findings: These include hyperdense areas within the sinuses, which are indicative of fungal involvement and mucin accumulation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bent and Kuhn described a diagnostic criterion for AFRS. They found 11 important clinical features, 5 of which were termed major criteria and the remaining 6 features as minor criteria. These criteria includes:

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, Volume 1, Page No. 1049

choices.text: Inhibition of M2 receptor
Neuraminidase inhibition
Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA polymerase
Apoptosis of infected cells

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Oseltamivir as an antiviral agent is? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Neuraminidase inhibition

 

Oseltamivir, commonly known by its brand name Tamiflu, is an antiviral medication primarily used to treat and prevent Influenza A and B. Its mechanism of action is as follows:

 

  • Neuraminidase inhibition: Oseltamivir works by inhibiting the viral enzyme neuraminidase. Neuraminidase is crucial for the viral life cycle because it cleaves sialic acid residues on the surface of host cells and on viral proteins, which facilitates the release of new viral particles from infected cells. By inhibiting neuraminidase, Oseltamivir prevents the release and spread of the virus, thus limiting the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inhibition of M2 receptor: This is incorrect. The M2 receptor is targeted by another antiviral drug, Amantadine, which is used against influenza A by inhibiting viral uncoating.

 

Option C. Inhibition of RNA dependent DNA polymerase: This is incorrect. Inhibition of RNA-dependent DNA polymerase is the mechanism of action for antiretroviral drugs like reverse transcriptase inhibitors used in HIV treatment.

 

Option D. Apoptosis of infected cells: This is incorrect. Inducing apoptosis of infected cells is not the mechanism by which Oseltamivir works. It primarily prevents the release of new viral particles rather than directly inducing cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor that is used to treat Influenza A and B. Inhibition of viral neuraminidase inhibits the release of viral progeny from the infected host cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tricuspid stenosis

 

The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) are key indicators for diagnosing tricuspid stenosis.

 

Tricuspid Stenosis causes an obstruction to right ventricular inflow, which leads to an increase in right atrial pressure, reflected as a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP. The mid-diastolic murmur is due to the turbulent flow across the narrowed tricuspid valve during diastole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral Stenosis: While it can cause a diastolic murmur, it typically does not cause a prominent 'a' wave in the JVP unless there is secondary pulmonary hypertension affecting the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Mitral Regurgitation: This would cause a holosystolic murmur and, if severe enough to cause pulmonary hypertension, may indirectly cause changes in the JVP, but it does not directly cause a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Option D. Tricuspid Regurgitation: This condition causes a large 'v' wave in the JVP due to backflow of blood into the right atrium during systole, not a prominent 'a' wave.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A prominent 'a' wave in JVP and a mid-diastolic murmur are indicative of tricuspid stenosis, a condition causing right ventricular inflow obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Median

 

  • The uvula vesicae is formed by the prostate's median lobe.
  • The uvula vesicae is a slight elevation on the trigone immediately posterior to the urethral orifice caused by the median lobe of the prostate.
  • In benign prostatic hypertrophy, it is frequently enlarged.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior: The anterior lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the anterior fibromuscular stroma, is found at the front of the prostate, facing the pubic symphysis. Contrary to the other sections of the prostate, this area is primarily made up of fibromuscular tissue and contains fewer glandular elements. It doesn't commonly give rise to clinical conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or prostate cancer.

 

Option B. Posterior: The posterior lobe is located at the back of the prostate, facing the rectum. This part of the prostate is significant clinically because it's the most common site for the development of prostate cancer. During a digital rectal exam, the physician can palpate this lobe, and any firm or irregular nodules felt here could suggest malignancy.

 

Option D. Lateral: The lateral lobes are the large bilateral portions of the prostate on either side of the urethra. These are the most voluminous parts of the prostate and are typically the primary sites involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition in older men where the prostate enlarges and can cause urinary obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle lobe or median lobe of the prostate is situated between the ejaculatory ducts and the urethra. When the median lobe enlarges due to conditions like benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), it can project into the bladder, forming a structure called the "uvula vesicae." It is also known as Lietaud’s uvula. This growth can cause urinary symptoms by obstructing the bladder neck.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for Cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. What would be the diagnosis according to the given image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gallbladder polyp

 

Given image shows a Gall bladder specimen revealing numerous polyps.

 

Gall Bladder Polyp

 

Majority are either adenomyomatosis or cholesterol polyps and have no malignant potential.

True adenomatous polyp occurs in 0.3–0.5% of the population. The risk of malignant transformation increases with increasing size of the polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholesterosis and Option D. Strawberry Gall bladder: The interior of the gallbladder looks something like a strawberry. The yellow specks (submucous aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters) correspond to the seeds of a strawberry.

 

 

Option C. Gall bladder Carcinoma: Gall bladder Carcinoma specimen resemble chronic cholecystitis on gross examination, often with a thickened wall and possibly a mass. However, the image provided does not show the characteristics typically associated with carcinoma, such as a mass or irregular thickening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallbladder polyps, as seen in the image, are common and typically benign, with the risk of malignancy increasing with polyp size. Accurate identification is crucial for appropriate management.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 79, 1709

choices.text: Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV
Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV
Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the probable diagnosis, cell, and virus associated with the image given below? (AIIMS NOV 2021)

 

(RS cell: Reed - Sternberg cell, HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus, CMV: Cytomegalovirus, EBV: Epstein-Barr virus)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV

 

The probable diagnosis, cell, and virus from the given clinical scenario and the histopathological image are Hodgkin's lymphoma, Reed-Sternberg cells (RS cells), and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) respectively.

 

Identification of Reed-Sternberg cells and their variants is essential for the diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are large cells (≥45 μm in diameter) with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes, each with a large inclusion-like nucleolus about the size of a small lymphocyte (5–7 μm in diameter).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, RS cell, EBV: Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma does not typically feature Reed-Sternberg cells. While EBV can be associated with some types of Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, the presence of RS cells is specific to Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Option B. Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV: Kaposi sarcoma is associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and often presents with spindle cells and slit-like vascular spaces, not Reed-Sternberg cells. It is more commonly associated with HIV.

 

Option D. Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV: Infectious mononucleosis is usually associated with EBV, not CMV, and while it can cause atypical lymphocytosis, it does not produce Reed-Sternberg cells, which are specific to Hodgkin's lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hodgkin's lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, and it is often associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), particularly in specific subtypes.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl is seen for primary amenorrhea. She has not development of breasts or hair in the pubic or axillary region. Her height is 155cm and her weight is 48 kg. She has bilateral inguinal masses. On USG examination, the uterus, fallopian tube, and ovary are absent. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism

 

Explanation:

 

  • The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.
  • In this question, bilateral inguinal masses (undescended testis), absent ovary, also there is absent uterus and fallopian tubes, all pointing to a conclusion that patient can be of XY karyotype. Because if female reproductive tract is absent, there must be mullerian inhibiting substance present which comes from Y chromosome.
  • Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism can occur in disorders such as FSH or LH receptor mutations.
  • Now, in a XY individual with a defect in LH/hCG receptor, testis’ Sertoli cells will produce Anti-mullerian hormone which will not let uterus, fallopian tube, cervix, upper vagina to develop. Leydi cells will not produce testosterone due to which wolffian duct development is impaired and the testes fail to descend. They appear female at birth and at puberty present with primary amenorrhea. They lack breast development and pubic hair development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome: Androgen insensitivity syndrome individuals have normal breast development.

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: Turner's syndrome karyotype is XO.

 

Option D. Polycystic ovary syndrome: In Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) ovary and uterus is present, so can’t be answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism can present as primary amenorrhea with absent uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries in an XY individual, with bilateral inguinal masses indicating undescended testes.

choices.text: A patient who is in acute crisis
A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning
A patient with strong ego and high motivation

questions.text: In which of the following patients, supportive psychotherapy would not be preferred? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A patient with strong ego and high motivation

 

A patient with strong ego and high motivation: Advanced psychoanalysis are advised due to the patient's capacity for deep psychological work. Supportive psychotherapy, which focuses on immediate coping, is considered less effective for this patient.

 

Supportive psychotherapy is aimed at supporting the patient through reassurance, guidance, and a therapeutic relationship without delving deeply into their past or cognitive processes. It is particularly useful for patients in acute crisis, those with cognitive deficits, and severely ill patients with deficient ego functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient who is in acute crisis: Supportive psychotherapy is highly appropriate as it focuses on providing immediate support and reassurance without exploring complex underlying issues.

 

Option B. A patient with cognitive deficits: These patients may struggle to understand more intricate forms of psychotherapy, making supportive psychotherapy a suitable option to provide essential support and stabilization.

 

Option C. A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning: These patients often have low frustration tolerance and cannot handle the complexities of other forms of therapy, making supportive psychotherapy beneficial to provide stability and support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supportive psychotherapy is not preferred for patients with a strong ego and high motivation, as they can handle and benefit from more complex and deeper forms of therapy.

questions.text: What is the window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 41/2 hours

 

The window period for the administration of intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) in the case of an acute ischemic stroke is 4½ hours from the onset of symptoms. This time frame is critical as rtPA is most effective when administered early, aiming to dissolve the blood clot and restore blood flow to the affected part of the brain, thus minimizing or reversing the damage caused by the stroke.

 

Indications:

 

  • After Clinical diagnosis of stroke established
  • If onset of symptoms to time of drug administration </= 4.5 hours
  • If age >/= 18 years
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory
  • Consent given by patient or surrogate

 

Contraindications:

 

  • Coma/stupor/ recent MI.
  • Major surgery in last 14 days/ GI bleeding in last 21 days/ minor stroke symptoms.
  • Rapidly improving symptoms.
  • Sustained BP > 185/110 mmHg despite treatment.
  • Platelets < 100,000; HCT < 25%; glucose < 50 or > 400 mg/dL.
  • Use of heparin within 48hrs and prolonged PTT or elevated INR.
  • Prior stroke or head injury within 3 months; prior intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic window for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke using rtPA is up to 4½ hours from symptom onset, and strict criteria must be met to ensure the safety and efficacy of treatment. This timeframe is crucial for maximizing the potential benefits of the treatment while minimizing risks.

questions.text: Calculate for Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patent with burn involving the chest and abdomen right arm and right thigh (circumferental): (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 31.5% 

 

According to the ‘Rule of Nine’, BSA is calculated as: 

 

  • Chest and Abdomen = 18%
  • Right Arm (not entire upper limb) = 4.5%
  • Right Thigh = 9%

 

Total = 18% + 4.5% + 9% = 31.5%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. It divides the body into sections that represent approximately 9% of the total surface area, facilitating quick and effective assessment and treatment planning for burn patients.

questions.text: A patient arrives with a clean-cut injury, no lacerations. He reports receiving his last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago. What would be the recommended course of action? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Single dose tetanus toxoid

 

The recommended course of action for a patient with a clean-cut injury who received their last tetanus vaccination approximately a decade ago is to administer a single dose of tetanus toxoid. This recommendation is based on the standard guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis in wound management.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is associated with increased risk of urinary tract infections? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors work by promoting the excretion of glucose through the urine. This increased urinary glucose can create an environment that promotes the growth of bacteria, thereby increasing the risk of urinary tract infections. This class of drugs is well known for its association with UTIs and genital infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects include weight gain, edema, and an increased risk of heart failure.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It works by increasing incretin levels, which in turn increase insulin secretion and decrease glucagon secretion. Sitagliptin is not commonly associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

 

Option D. Metformin: Metformin is a biguanide that decreases hepatic glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity. It is not associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections. Common side effects of metformin include gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea and abdominal discomfort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin, an SGLT2 inhibitor, is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to its mechanism of increasing glucose excretion in the urine. This patient’s recurrent UTIs could be related to her use of dapagliflozin.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 38-year-old female who is experiencing substantial hair loss for 4 months and has a history of COVID-19 infection 8 months ago? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Telogen effluvium

 

  • The pattern of hair loss in this clinical scenario is telogen effluvium.
  • The condition described is characterized by the sudden onset of scalp hair loss, typically occurring one to two months after a triggering event, which may include high fever, infections (such as Cholera, Typhoid, or COVID-19), surgery, trauma, starvation, myocardial infarction (MI), pregnancy, or hemorrhage.
  • This type of hair loss is associated with an increase in the shedding of telogen club hairs due to the premature termination of the anagen proliferative phase of the hair cycle following a period of significant stress.
  • When telogen hair shedding lasts for more than six months, it is termed “chronic diffuse telogen hair loss.” The main causes of chronic diffuse telogen hair loss include thyroid conditions (both hyper- and hypothyroidism), severe iron deficiency anemia, acrodermatitis enteropathica, and malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgenetic alopecia: Typically presents as a patterned hair loss and is more gradual. It is driven by genetic factors and hormonal influences and does not usually have a sudden onset associated with illness.

 

Option C. Alopecia areata:

  • An autoimmune condition where the body's immune system attacks hair follicles.
  • It results in small, round, and smooth patches of hair loss, which can coalesce but often do not cause complete hair loss.

 

 

  • It's not directly linked to illnesses like COVID-19 and does not typically present as diffuse hair loss across the entire scalp as suggested in the question.

 

Option D. Trichotillomania:

  • A psychological condition where individuals compulsively pull out their own hair, leading to hair loss.
  • Hair loss pattern tends to be irregular with varied length hairs, and examination often reveals broken hairs.

 

 

 

  • The history provided does not suggest any compulsive behavior or the typical patchy, irregular pattern seen with trichotillomania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring hair loss characterized by the diffuse shedding of hair resulting from the early entry of hair into the telogen phase (the resting phase of the hair cycle). This condition is often triggered by significant physiological stress, severe illness, or major life events.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 32.24, 32.39, 32.40, 86.17, 89.6, 89.14, 89.17, 89.20 89.24, 89.25, 89.46

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 1509

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 387

questions.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) functions to stabilize the image on the retina during head movement. What is the ratio of eye velocity to head velocity, known as the VOR gain?  (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) gain is 1, indicating that the eyes move at a compensatory velocity equal to the velocity of the head, but in the opposite direction.

 

The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) allows for eye movements in the opposite direction of head movement to maintain steady gaze and prevent retinal image slip. Nerves involved are 3, 6 & 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct VOR gain is crucial for visual stability. A gain of 1 allows for precise compensation for head movements, ensuring that the visual environment remains stable, which is vital for tasks that involve motion and require steady vision, such as reading while in a moving vehicle or playing sports.

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation
Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
Respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation
Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.32, pCO2 = 50, HCO3- = 29. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation

 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate:

 

pH = 7.12 (<7.4 = acidemic/acidosis) → Metabolic vs respiratory (pCO2 > 40= Respiratory drive is towards acidosis while metabolic [HCO3-] is towards alkalosis) → Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation (Every 10 ↑ pCO2 = ↑4 HCO3- = Chronic).

 

These findings are characteristic of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. In respiratory acidosis, the body compensates by increasing renal reabsorption of bicarbonate to buffer the excess hydrogen ions resulting from elevated CO2 levels, which shifts the pH back towards normal. This compensation is a slower process and suggests a chronic respiratory condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where ABG shows a low pH and high pCO2 with compensatory high bicarbonate, the diagnosis is typically respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. This is indicative of a chronic condition where the body adjusts bicarbonate levels to buffer the increased acidity due to CO2 retention.

 

Reference - Harrison/Acid-Base Disturbances

choices.text: Hydrogen peroxide
Methyl paraben
Bleaching powder

questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used as a disinfectant but not a sanitizer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen peroxide

 

Process of bringing down levels of pathogenic organisms on inanimate surfaces to reduce the chances of cross-infection is called as sanitization.

 

Process of destroying all pathogenic organisms is called as disinfection.

 

Process of eliminating all microorganisms in both vegetative and spore state are eliminated from a surface or medium is called as sterilization.

 

Hydrogen peroxide works by producing destructive hydroxyl free radicals that can attack membrane lipids, DNA, and other essential cell components. Catalase, produced by aerobic organisms and facultative anaerobes that possess cytochrome systems, can protect cells from metabolically produced hydrogen peroxide by degrading hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. This defense is overwhelmed by the concentrations used for disinfection.

 

Disinfection or sterilization of cystoscopes, endoscopes, tubing’s, and metal instruments can be done with liquid form of hydrogen peroxide while gaseous form can be used for fogging. It is also used in plasma sterilization.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Penicillin, an antibiotic. It is neither a disinfectant nor a sanitizer.

 

Option C. Methyl paraben is a type of paraben. Parabens are chemicals that are often used as preservatives to give products a longer shelf life.

 

Option D. Household bleaching powder (sodium hypochlorite) is used as a disinfectant in hospitals. Diluted solutions can be used for sanitizing surfaces.

 

Educational Objective

 

Hydrogen peroxide is used as a disinfectant because it effectively destroys a wide range of pathogenic organisms. It is not typically used as a sanitizer, which is a process aimed at reducing, rather than completely eliminating, pathogenic organisms on surfaces.

questions.text: Vitamin C cannot be produced in humans due to lack of? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L-gulonolactone oxidase

 

Most animals and plants can synthesize ascorbic acid from glucose. Man, higher primates, guineapigs and bats are the only species which cannot synthesize ascorbic acid (block in gulonolactone oxidase step). They lack the genes responsible for the synthesis of this enzyme.

 

Details of L-gulonolactone Oxidase:

  • Role: This enzyme is responsible for converting L-gulonolactone to ascorbic acid (vitamin C).
  • Deficiency: Humans, higher primates, guinea pigs, and certain other species lack this enzyme due to mutations or absence of the gene encoding it, which blocks the synthesis of ascorbic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Xylitol reductase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of xylitol to xylulose but is not related to the synthesis of vitamin C.

 

Option C. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: This enzyme complex plays a critical role in converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration but is not involved in vitamin C synthesis.

 

Option D. UDP glucose dehydrogenase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of UDP-glucuronic acid from UDP-glucose but has no role in vitamin C production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Humans cannot synthesize vitamin C due to the lack of the enzyme L-gulonolactone oxidase, which is necessary for the final step in the biosynthetic pathway of ascorbic acid from glucose.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are associated with Metastatic calcification except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin D deficiency

 

Metastatic calcification is associated with Hypercalcemia (Vitamin D toxicity), not Vitamin D deficiency.

 

 

Tumors having Dystrophic calcification: Psammoma bodies present

 

M – Meningioma, Mesothelioma

 

O – Ovary (Serous cystadenoma)

 

S – Salivary gland tumor

 

T – Thyroid (Papillary thyroid cancer)

 

P – Prolactinoma

 

G – Glucagonoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal failure: Chronic kidney disease can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism and hyperphosphatemia, both of which contribute to hypercalcemia and subsequent metastatic calcification.

 

Option B. Accumulation of calcium phosphate: This typically occurs in the context of renal failure or parathyroid hormone-related issues, leading to metastatic calcification.

 

Option D Parathyroid activation secretion: Hyperparathyroidism, whether primary or secondary, causes an increase in serum calcium, leading to metastatic calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metastatic calcification is associated with conditions that lead to hypercalcemia, not with conditions that result in normal or low calcium levels, such as Vitamin D deficiency.

questions.text:
Arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following findings:(NEET PG 2021)

  • pH: 7.52
  • HCO3: 30 mEq/L
  • PaCO2: 45 mmHg
  • Na: 123 mEq/L
  • K: 3.2 mEq/L
  • Cl: 67 mEq/L

What is the cause of her ABG findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Persistent vomiting

 

The ABG report indicates the patient has metabolic alkalosis, as evidenced by the elevated pH (7.52) and increased bicarbonate (HCO3) level (30 mEq/L). The slight increase in PaCO2 (45 mmHg) is a compensatory response to metabolic alkalosis, as the body attempts to retain CO2 to balance the pH.

 

Persistent vomiting leads to a loss of gastric acid (HCl), which results in metabolic alkalosis. The electrolyte disturbances seen here (hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and hyponatremia) are typical of persistent vomiting. Vomiting causes a loss of hydrogen ions (leading to increased bicarbonate), chloride (hypochloremia), and potassium (hypokalemia), along with fluid loss, which can dilute serum sodium levels, leading to hyponatremia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) typically presents with metabolic acidosis (low pH and low HCO3) rather than metabolic alkalosis. Additionally, DKA is usually associated with hyperkalemia rather than hypokalemia.

 

Option C. Septic shock: Septic shock usually causes metabolic acidosis due to lactic acidosis from poor tissue perfusion. It does not typically present with metabolic alkalosis and the specific electrolyte disturbances seen here.

 

Option D. Renal tubular acidosis: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is characterized by a defect in the kidneys' ability to acidify the urine, leading to metabolic acidosis. The ABG findings in RTA would show a low pH and low bicarbonate levels, which is opposite to what is observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Persistent vomiting can lead to hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia. This is due to the loss of gastric acid and electrolytes, and the characteristic ABG findings include elevated pH and bicarbonate levels. Treatment often involves fluid and electrolyte replacement, particularly with normal saline to correct chloride levels.

questions.text: Which of the following feature is correct on the basis of given karyotype? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gynecomastia and long limbs

 

Given karyotyping image shows '47, XXY' abnormality, which is seen in Klinefelter's syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Flat occiput: This feature is typically seen in Down syndrome (Trisomy 21).

 

Option C. Webbing of neck and lymphedema: These are characteristic features of Turner syndrome (45, X).

 

Option D. Short stature and polydactyly: These are features seen in Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter syndrome (47, XXY) is characterized by gynecomastia, long limbs, small testes, and infertility.

 

Ref: Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 316-317

choices.text: Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 6 mins of standing
Decrease in Systolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 min of standing
Decrease in diastolic blood pressure 20 mmHg after 3 mins of standing

questions.text: True about the definition of Postural Hypotension: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decrease in systolic blood pressure 20 mm Hg after 3 mins of standing

 

“3-20-10” mnemonic can aid in remembering the definition of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Sustained fall of SBP > 20mmHg /DBP > 10mmHg after 3 mins of standing. Usually, it is accompanied by a rise in HR. Absence of increase in heart rate suggest neurogenic/autonomic dysfunction.

 

Cause of Orthostatic Hypotension:

 

  • Cardiac pump failure
  • Hypovolemia
  • Endocrinopathies: AI, Pheochromocytoma.
  • Venous pooling
  • Medications

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and B: These options extend the timing to 6 minutes, which is not standard for the initial assessment of orthostatic hypotension.

 

Option D: Specifies a diastolic drop which should be 10 mmHg, not 20 mmHg, thus making it incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:
