Postural hypotension, also known as orthostatic hypotension, is defined as a significant drop in blood pressure when a person stands up from a sitting or lying position. The correct definition, as per the consensus, includes a decrease in systolic blood pressure of 20 mmHg or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg within 3 minutes of standing. The answer C correctly reflects the component of this definition regarding the systolic blood pressure drop.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology, chap 21/695

questions.text: Which pathogen causes attachment-effacement lesion in the intestinal mucosa? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enteropathogenic Escherichia coli


Attaching-and-effacing is the “hallmark” of the EPEC infections, a lesion that is characterized by the intimate attachment of the bacteria to the host epithelial cell membrane and the effacement of the microvilli. This mechanism is a hallmark of EPEC infections, leading to copious watery diarrhea, especially in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC): Incorrect: ETEC causes watery diarrhea through the production of enterotoxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) or cyclic GMP (cGMP) levels, leading to fluid and electrolyte loss. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option C. Enteroinvasive Escherichia coli (EIEC): Incorrect: EIEC invades and destroys epithelial cells lining the colon, leading to fever, cramping, watery diarrhea, and dysentery with scant, bloody stools. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Option D. Diffusely adherent Escherichia coli (DAEC): Incorrect: DAEC is known for its diffuse adherence pattern to epithelial cells, causing persistent diarrhea in children. It does not cause attachment-effacement lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic with persistent headaches and facial pressure that have progressively worsened over the past month. The pain is primarily located around his forehead and the bridge of his nose, worsening when he bends forward. He has no history of recent trauma and denies any significant nasal discharge or fever. Suspecting sinusitis, the physician orders a specific radiographic view to best evaluate his frontal sinuses along with other nearby structures. What is the commonly used name for this specific radiographic view?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Caldwell view

 

Explanation:


The Caldwell view, also known as the occipitofrontal view, is specifically designed for optimal visualization of the frontal sinuses. This view is obtained by positioning the patient’s forehead and nose against the radiographic film with the X-ray beam angled 15–20° caudally. This technique provides detailed imaging of the frontal sinuses, ethmoid sinuses, superior orbital fissure, and other related structures, making it ideal for evaluating sinus conditions.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Waters view: This view is primarily used to assess the maxillary sinuses and does not provide the optimal angle for visualizing the frontal sinuses. It involves positioning that differs from the Caldwell view, focusing more on the infraorbital region.

 

Option C. Towne view: The Towne view is utilized for examining the occipital region and posterior cranial fossa, not specifically for sinus evaluation, and does not target the frontal sinuses.

 

Option D. Lateral view: The lateral view provides a side profile of the skull, including the sinuses, but lacks the angulation and detail required for optimal assessment of the frontal sinuses, unlike the Caldwell view.

 

Educational Objective:


The Caldwell view is the preferred radiographic technique for evaluating the frontal sinuses due to its specific positioning and angulation, which provide detailed visualization of this area. Understanding which radiographic view is best suited for different anatomical structures is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of sinus-related conditions.

questions.text:
Blood examination shows pancytopenia, which can be correct? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Megaloblastic anemia
  2. Hairy cell leukemia
  3. MDS with hypocellular BM
  4. APML
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Megaloblastic anemia (hypocellular phase), hairy cell leukemia, and MDS (hypocellular bone marrow) can show pancytopenia.

 

  1. Megaloblastic anemia: This type of anemia, often caused by vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, can lead to pancytopenia, especially in its more severe or hypocellular phase. The bone marrow in megaloblastic anemia can show hypercellularity with ineffective hematopoiesis, but in some cases, it can present as hypocellular, contributing to pancytopenia.
  2. Hairy cell leukemia: This is a type of chronic B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder. It is commonly associated with pancytopenia due to bone marrow infiltration by hairy cells and associated fibrosis, which suppresses normal hematopoiesis.
  3. MDS with hypocellular BM: Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) are a group of hematologic conditions characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis and dysplasia in one or more of the myeloid cell lines. In cases of MDS with a hypocellular bone marrow, pancytopenia can occur due to the reduced production of blood cells.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) is typically not associated with pancytopenia. APML usually presents with leukocytosis or normal white cell counts, along with thrombocytopenia and anemia. However, severe pancytopenia is not a characteristic feature, and therefore, APML is not typically associated with pancytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pancytopenia –

 

I. Aplastic anemia

 

II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity e.g.

 

  1. Myelodysplastic syndromes
  2. Hypersplenism
  3. Megaloblastic anemia

 

III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (page 314)

 

IV. Bone marrow infiltrations e.g.

 

  1. Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  2. Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  3. Storage diseases
  4. Osteopetrosis
  5. Myelofibrosis

questions.text: Which of the following binds to tyrosine kinase receptors?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insulin

 

Option B. Insulin: Insulin binds to tyrosine kinase receptors known as insulin receptors (IR). When insulin binds to these receptors, it activates the tyrosine kinase activity of the receptor, resulting in the autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues and the initiation of intracellular signaling cascades. Therefore, insulin binds to tyrosine kinase receptors.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): LH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. LH binds to its specific G-protein-coupled receptor (LH receptor) on the surface of target cells, leading to the activation of intracellular signaling pathways via G proteins.

 

Option C. TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone): TSH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. TSH binds to the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR), which belongs to the family of G-protein-coupled receptors. Activation of TSHR leads to intracellular signaling through G proteins, not tyrosine kinase activation.

 

Option D. TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone): TRH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. It acts on its specific G-protein-coupled receptor (TRH receptor) to initiate signaling pathways through G proteins, similar to TSH.

 

Educational objective:

 

The insulin and IGF-I receptors have intrinsic ligand-activated tyrosine kinase activity. By binding to these receptors, these hormones will activate tyrosine kinases inside the cell which in turn phosphorylates important enzymes for involved in a number of processes such as metabolism, growth and differentiation and also inflammatory response.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed./pg – 508

questions.text: Which of the following is not caused by parvovirus B19?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Petechial rash

 

Parvovirus B19 is known to cause several conditions, including erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash in children. It can also affect red blood cells, leading to pure red cell aplasia and aplastic crisis, especially in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders. In pregnant women, parvovirus B19 infection can cause hydrops fetalis, a serious condition characterized by severe fetal anemia and fluid accumulation. However, petechial rash is not typically associated with parvovirus B19 infection. Petechial rashes are more commonly linked to other viral infections or conditions that cause thrombocytopenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pure red cell aplasia: Parvovirus B19 can infect erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, leading to pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with compromised immune systems or underlying hematologic disorders.

 

Option B. Hydrops fetalis: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to hydrops fetalis due to severe fetal anemia, making this a well-documented complication.

 

Option C. Aplastic crisis: In individuals with chronic hemolytic anemias, such as sickle cell disease, parvovirus B19 infection can precipitate an aplastic crisis by temporarily halting red blood cell production in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 can cause pure red cell aplasia, aplastic crisis, and hydrops fetalis, but it is not associated with petechial rash.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selegiline

 

The patient's symptoms of rigidity, tremors, and blank facial expressions are suggestive of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that is used in the management of Parkinson's disease. It works by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine, thereby increasing its availability in the brain and helping to alleviate symptoms like rigidity and tremors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia. While it can be used in Parkinson's disease patients who experience psychosis, it is not a first-line treatment for the primary motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

 

Option B. Donepezil: Donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. It enhances cholinergic function by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine in the brain. It is not typically used for treating Parkinson's disease.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic and can actually worsen Parkinson's disease symptoms. It blocks dopamine receptors, which could exacerbate the dopamine deficiency characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that increases dopamine availability in the brain and is used to manage the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as rigidity and tremors.

choices.text: Glucose tolerance test

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is non-essential in the evaluation of mosaic Turner syndrome? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-nuclear antibodies

 

Out of the provided choices, the presence of anti-nuclear antibodies is not a necessary factor when investigating mosaic Turner syndrome.

 

Mosaic Turner syndrome is non-hereditary in nature. It emerges from a chance incident during the phase of cell division in the initial stages of fetal development in the impacted individual. Consequently, a portion of an individual's cells retain the standard two sex chromosomes, whereas another set of cells possess just a single X chromosome copy.

 

Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

 

Option B. Glucose Tolerance Test: Important for detecting glucose intolerance or diabetes, which is common in Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Audiometry: Used to assess hearing loss, which is more prevalent in individuals with Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Echocardiography: Critical for evaluating congenital heart defects, such as coarctation of the aorta or bicuspid aortic valve, which are common in Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While glucose tolerance testing, audiometry, and echocardiography are essential in the evaluation of Turner syndrome, testing for anti-nuclear antibodies is not necessary unless there is a clinical suspicion of an associated autoimmune disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not need dose adjustment in renal failure? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Linagliptin

 

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. Unlike other DPP-4 inhibitors, linagliptin is primarily excreted via the enterohepatic system, with only a small fraction eliminated by the kidneys. Therefore, it does not require dose adjustments in patients with renal impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sitagliptin: This DPP-4 inhibitor is primarily excreted by the kidneys, and its dose usually needs to be adjusted in patients with renal impairment.

 

Option B. Saxagliptin: Saxagliptin and its active metabolite are primarily eliminated by the kidneys, necessitating dose adjustments in patients with renal failure.

 

Option C. Vildagliptin: Vildagliptin is partially excreted by the kidneys, and dose adjustment is recommended in patients with moderate to severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin is a unique DPP-4 inhibitor that does not require dose adjustments in patients with renal failure due to its primary excretion via the enterohepatic system. This makes it an advantageous option for managing type 2 diabetes in patients with compromised renal function.

questions.text: Mr. Seth recently underwent surgery to remove a parathyroid gland due to hyperparathyroidism. The surgeon informed the patient that one or more of the parathyroid glands may be transferred to another location during the surgery to protect them or due to their location. The parathyroid is commonly transferred to? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Brachioradialis

 

Explanation:

 

The most common site for the relocation of the parathyroid gland(s) is in the forearm muscle, specifically the nondominant side brachioradialis. Transplantation to this location provides several advantages:

  • Accessibility: The forearm location is easily accessible for potential future surgical interventions if necessary.
  • Monitoring: This location allows for straightforward monitoring of parathyroid function using simple clinical tests.
  • Functionality: The transplanted gland(s) will continue to produce parathyroid hormone normally, aiding in the regulation of calcium levels in the body.
  • Ease of Removal: If there is disease recurrence after surgery, the forearm location facilitates easy removal.
  • Typically, a total of 12 to 14 pieces are transplanted in a type of heterotopic transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triceps: Triceps is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation due to less accessibility and monitoring challenges compared to the brachioradialis.

 

Option B. Biceps: Biceps is also not commonly used for parathyroid transplantation because it does not offer the same ease of access and monitoring advantages as the brachioradialis.

 

Option C. Sartorius: Sartorius is not a preferred site for parathyroid transplantation. The forearm muscle (brachioradialis) is favored for its convenience and monitoring benefits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The brachioradialis muscle in the forearm is the most common site for parathyroid gland relocation during surgery due to its ease of access, convenient monitoring, and straightforward removal if needed.

choices.text: MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in all of these conditions, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg

 

Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg: This is a contraindication for thrombolysis. Elevated blood pressure increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications during thrombolysis. Therefore, blood pressure must be controlled to below 185/110 mmHg before initiating thrombolytic therapy.

 

Thrombolysis is a treatment used to dissolve blood clots in certain types of stroke patients. It is most effective when administered within a specific time window from the onset of symptoms and under certain conditions to ensure patient safety and efficacy of the treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct: This indicates that the infarct size is within a range that is generally considered safe for thrombolysis. More extensive infarcts (> 1/3rd of the middle cerebral artery territory) are a contraindication due to the higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

 

Option C. Ischemia < 2 hours and D. Onset of symptoms < 4 hours: Both of these options fall within the critical time window for thrombolysis, which is generally considered up to 4.5 hours from symptom onset. Treatment within this time frame can significantly improve outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombolysis is contraindicated in patients with blood pressure higher than 185/110 mmHg at the time of treatment.

questions.text: Sameer was tried in a court in the case of Sanjay’s murder in the park. Sahil appeared in court and stated that he saw Sameer with an axe in his hand while passing the park. What is this evidence known as? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indirect

 

This type of evidence in known as an indirect evidence or circumstantial evidence.

 

This evidence providing only a basis for inference about the fact in dispute and it is not an eyewitness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hostile: Refers to a witness who is antagonistic or adverse to the party who called them to testify.

 

Option C. Direct: Evidence that directly proves a fact, such as an eyewitness account of the crime being committed.

 

Option D. Hearsay: Evidence based on what someone else said, not on the direct knowledge of the witness, and typically inadmissible in court due to its second-hand nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indirect or circumstantial evidence suggests a fact but does not directly prove it. In this case, seeing Sameer with an axe near the park suggests involvement but does not directly prove his guilt.

questions.text: A patient presents with a large, deep wound and the healthcare provider decides to use a specific wound-healing procedure. What is the principle behind the wound-healing procedure shown in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Negative pressure wound therapy

 

Negative pressure wound therapy, also known as vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) therapy, involves the application of negative pressure to a wound using a sealed dressing connected to a vacuum pump.

 

  • This therapy helps in wound healing by several mechanisms: it removes excess fluid and infectious materials from the wound, improves blood flow to the area, reduces edema (swelling), and promotes the formation of granulation tissue.
  • It is often used for large, deep wounds, chronic wounds, and complex surgical wounds to accelerate the healing process.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

VAC therapy = vacuum assisted closure therapy

 

  1. Mechanism of action: VAC therapy involves the application of negative pressure (-125 mm of hg) to a wound to promote wound healing. The negative pressure removes excess fluid and promotes the formation of granulation tissue and new blood vessels.
  2. Indications: VAC therapy is commonly used for the management of complex wounds, such as diabetic foot ulcers, pressure ulcers, and surgical wounds. It can also be used to manage wounds with high risk of infection.
  3. Procedure: VAC therapy involves placing a foam dressing over the wound and covering it with an adhesive film. A tube is then inserted through the film and connected to a vacuum pump, which applies negative pressure to the wound. The pressure can be adjusted to provide the optimal level of tension for the specific wound.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the clinic for her annual check-up. Her DEXA scan shows evidence of osteoporosis with a T-score of -3.0 at the lumbar spine. She is postmenopausal and has no other significant medical history. She is interested in pharmacological treatment options for her osteoporosis. What is the first-line management for postmenopausal osteoporosis in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bisphosphonates

 

Bisphosphonates, such as alendronate and risedronate, are often considered the first-line therapy for postmenopausal osteoporosis. These drugs inhibit bone resorption and have been shown to reduce the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women with osteoporosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: While estrogen replacement therapy can be effective for preventing bone loss, it is generally not recommended as first-line treatment for osteoporosis due to potential risks, such as an increased risk of breast cancer, thromboembolic events, and cardiovascular disease.

 

Option C. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is sometimes used in osteoporosis treatment. It is not usually considered first-line treatment but may be an option for those who cannot tolerate bisphosphonates.

 

Option D. Combined Oral Contraceptives: Combined oral contraceptives are not used for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. They are generally used in reproductive-age women for contraception and are not suitable for postmenopausal women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bisphosphonates are the first-line management for postmenopausal osteoporosis due to their effectiveness in inhibiting bone resorption and reducing fracture risk. Estrogen and raloxifene are alternative options but are not typically first-line treatments due to their associated risks and less robust efficacy compared to bisphosphonates. Combined oral contraceptives are not suitable for postmenopausal osteoporosis treatment.

questions.text: A woman with a history of painful genital ulcers 1 year back has a neonate of 1 week who has lesions on face and body with neurological symptoms. What is the likely infection? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus)

 

The question presents a scenario where a woman has a history of painful genital ulcers and has given birth to a neonate who now exhibits lesions on the face and body along with neurological symptoms. This clinical picture strongly suggests a neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) is known to cause painful genital ulcers in adults. The virus can remain latent in the body and reactivate later. During pregnancy or delivery, HSV can be transmitted to the neonate, particularly during vaginal delivery if there are active lesions or viral shedding. Neonatal HSV infection can present with vesicular lesions on the skin, eyes, and mouth, and it may also involve the central nervous system, leading to neurological symptoms. Neonatal HSV infection is a serious condition that requires prompt antiviral treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxoplasma: Incorrect because it does not cause painful genital ulcers in the mother or the described symptoms in the neonate.

 

Option B. Varicella: Incorrect because, although it can cause skin lesions in neonates, it is not linked with a history of painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Option D. CMV: Incorrect because CMV can cause congenital infections with neurological symptoms, but it is not associated with painful genital ulcers in the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A history of painful genital ulcers in the mother, especially when associated with neonatal lesions and neurological symptoms, is highly suggestive of neonatal HSV infection. HSV is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent severe outcomes in the neonate.
